In 1981 I made a quarter mold in auto shop with a friend. We used pipe with an inside diameter equal to a quarter. We cut off the thickness of a quarter then tack welded it onto a base plate. Using tire lead we melted these in to the mold and had quarters. We used these for the coke machine in the locker room and for video games in town.

Arcade video games were everywhere back then. Before our quarter forging, we would snap the plate off of he coin return slot. A penny could be pressed upwards then snapped to go up and come back down, triggering the micro switch that unlocked the game.

My buddy got busted in a pool hall doing this.

I worked with a guy whose father had games all over the valley. He had keys to the machines. We collected quarters and fixed machines. Mostly I played for free. I usually earned a roll or two of quarters for tagging along.

The summer I turned 18, my parents went on a camping road trip. I brought in a bunch of machines and had kegerator parties 2-3 nights a week. Just about every night was a small party of friends. We drank beer and played video games.

We blasted a stereo through someone’s bass amplifier. Yah, the sound quality wasn’t great, but it was loud.

:-)

Unsurprisingly, the video doesn't actually explain how the coin acceptor actually detects the type of coin and whether it is genuine or not. And only the very latest machines have the product sensing beams - older ones do not. That said, there is a delay before it cycles the dispenser again, and if you shake the machine, it will usually register as "product vended" and then will NOT cycle again.. So..if you buy something and it sticks, don't immediately start shaking it. WAIT a good 10 seconds or so, if the machine has the sensor, it will cycle again (and you might even get the stuck one, and the one behind it too - consider it payback for all the times it took your money and gave you nothing.

You can very easily cheat a vending machine. It detects the weight of the coin because of the featherweight it uses as a scale. Not what image is struck on the coin. I had a friend in the 8th grade and we tried it. We found some sheets of metal the same thickness as a quarter. Well, first we weighed a quarter on a scale and it weighed exactly 0.200 ounces. So we took that quarter, put it on the metal sheet, got a marker and drew circles on the metal sheet using the real quarter as a template.The fake coins we cut from the metal all weighed 0.205 ounces. We didn't think that that minute difference would matter. We just wanted to try this first so we cut only 40 to start with. We go to the bowling alley by his house that has an arcade in it as well as vending machines. When we tried our quarters, they spit out right away all the time. So we thought that maybe the 0.005 ounces more of our coins mattered. So we rode our bikes back to his house and filed them down on his dad's electric sander to exactly 0.200 ounces. When we got back to the arcade, they worked perfectly every time just like real quarters. In both the vending machines and the video games. We were elated! So when we ran out of our quarters, we went back to his house to make more. From each sheet of metal we were able to make 80 "quarters." Each sheet of metal cost $1.25 back then. This was back in the 1980s through the 1990s. Of course we couldn't use them in stores but we had all the free play on the video games and all the free snacks and pop we wanted from the vending machines. But we were smart. We didn't keep it all to ourselves. We told our friends and kids at school and made money off of them. We sold 80 of our quarters for $5. So they could buy $20 of stuff from vending machines or play video games. They sold well. So there is a way to cheat vending machines and that is how me and my friends did it when we were in school.

I actually programmed one of these things many years ago. The video gets the crucial part wrong.
The one that we used did not need any light sensors and there is definitely no "electromagnets". Most coins do not use magnetic metals so there is no reason use electromagnet on them.
Instead what they do is they use a coil and THE COIN BECOMES THE CORE OF THE ELECTROMAGNET for a very brief moment (how cool is that?)
The coin falls through a chute at a known speed and while it falls it is subjected to eddy currents at a known distance from the coil. While the coin is falling, the field generates eddy currents and this causes the entire setup to act as a transformer and draw current from coil power supply. The current draw is measured and given as a signal and strength of that signal over time is used to identify coins. The plot will depend on the dimensions of the coin (larger coins take more time to pass) and different alloys and thickness of the coin will result in a different strength of the signal. Some countries use coins with multiple bands of different alloys and this makes identification especially easy/reliable. Also, the worst coins are ones that are not round (for example octagonal outside or square holes in it) as they tend to generate slightly different signals when passing through the sensor.

I grew up helping my dad run his vending machine route. Many memories of helping him clean and repair machines, filling them, and counting and rolling up coins while we were driving to the next location. Plus moving machines in and out of locations, often up and down narrow stairs. Don't miss that part.
The previous version of the coin acceptor/rejector and counter is a masterwork of electromechanical design. First the coin goes through the ACMR (All Coin Mechanical Rejector) It sorted the coins by size and weight to put them into different chutes by denomination, and passed them by a magnet to detect steel slugs. It even had a mechanism that checked for the milling on the edges of the quarters and dimes.
Once the ACMR sorted and accepted them they went into chutes that counted each coin and transmitted pulses of current to the totalizer. A nickel sent one pulse, a dime two, and so on. Once enough total accumulated, it unlocked the rest of the machine to dispense a candy bar or whatever. SImple machines only allowed a single price across all selections, more complicated ones allowed multiple prices. Once an item got vended, the totalizer deducted the price, then dispensed change (mostly nickels, but later dimes and nickels )into the coin return chute until the totalizer counted back down to zero. The change tubes had a clever design to replenish them with nickels and dimes, and when full, divert them to the coin box.
If a coin was off weight or the milling was missing from the quarters or dimes, they diverted it to the coin return chute. Coins that were bent, and slugs that were ferrous or had holes in the middle (washers) got trapped in the ACMR, and you had to press the coin return lever that dumped everything into the coin return chute, and told the totalizer to return all accumulated value. (that was one of the tricks for when you didn't have a dime for a pay phone, you put a quarter into the candy machine and then pressed coin return, and you got back nickels and dimes.)
These coin mechanisms were complicated and needed to be kept clean and lubricated properly. We would routinely carry a couple of spare coin mechanisms to replace ones that had gotten sticky or jammed a lot. You could adjust them to be loose or tight in the tolerances of the coins, but tuning it tight meant that worn coins would be rejected because they were light and thinner, and irritating to legit customers.

That was the worst explanation for anything I've probably ever seen. More concerned about fancy graphics than actual details. How does it detect if a coin is fake? LASERS and MAGNETS. That's a pretty vague description. And the laser mechanism depicted would do nothing to detect if a coin is fake. There's no way for it to measure the size of the coin. That type of mechanism is for counting. It works just like one of those laser trip beams from a security system. There's a laser that shines on a detector and when coins roll past, they block the laser, and the detector counts how many times the laser is blocked and thus how many coins rolled past. I speak from 4 years experience as an electrical engineer. And from a hobby level interest in point of sale systems. Weird interest, I know lol. But good science channels get you interested in weird things. Laminar flow, anyone?

Using their vague "magnets and lasers" explanation, I could describe how a blu-ray player works. "How does a blu-ray player work? Magnets and lasers!" (a magnet for the motor and a laser to read the disc) but I've already included more information than this video did just by explaining why there are magnets and lasers in it beyond saying "so it can read discs." So you can see how it's an extremely vague and not very informative explanation.

I don't see a single comment saying what a wonderful explanation that was or how they understand or appreciate the coin mechanism in vending machines more now or how this made them realize there's more to it. These are the sorts of comments one usually sees on science videos. Even the most basic, most dumbed down ones still have some comments about what a positive learning experience it was. This video... none that I've seen. Maybe there are some peppered throughout, but they're few and far between if they are.

Alright I got a story for y’all and yes somehow it involves vending machines.

So back in my senior year of high school, me and my friends had a few free periods to spend and we did that by hanging out in the cafeteria, which had a few vending machines nearby.

So one day, I come in and my friends are all cheering like crazy like we had just graduated or something because of my junior friend ,at the time, had managed to get a free snack by using PENS by sticking both his hands under that little flap under the vending machine and manipulating that swirly thing that holds the snacks in place with the end of his pens.

He did by bouncing the swirly thing up and down repeatedly so as to push the snack forward. At the time, he had done this because the snack had gotten stuck near the bottom, but just out of reach so it’s justifiable until I came by at that moment.

This is where I had a eureka moment. I told my friend I can help him get more friends if he’s willing to listen. He said sure and asked me the idea.

I told him that if we combined our pens together using a rubber end to hold it together in the middle and manipulate it the same way he had done, we could get free snacks. He agreed.

And boy, oh boy, we had free snacks for DAYS. While we only were able to get snacks of the first and second rows and an occasional third, that was still a lot, so much so that we just gave it away for free at one point.

We had our few close calls and did caught once by a teacher, but she never reported us in and we never got by security cameras because of the location of the vending machine.

But thanks to COVID, we only spent half the year doing this and my school probably never noticed.

lol. That's the wrong question (the title) to ask. I'm a programmer. I majored in Computer Science. The way vending machines work is they will only accept coins that the machine was setup to accept. Everything else just gets rejected. For example if the machine was only setup to accept quarters, then it will return pennies, nickels, dimes, and anything else you put in. So, in other words the machine sees real pennies, nickels, and dimes as fake too in this case.

You know how they detected fake coins before laser/computers in phone booths?
Your coins would first go through a drop sort, sort the dime/nickel/quarter, and then drop
and bounce (yes bounce) into its slot.
A fake nickel that was pounded into a quarter shape would bounce higher and would not go into the quarter slot
and get rejected. Simple, requires no power and no mainteance.
That's ingenious.

Cinematic Vending Machine Animation detects fake coins

There was one time when my friend and I  were in middle school years back, and we went into the teacher’s lounge for the vending machine. No kids were usually allowed in there, but after school, some janitors used to let us in. One janitor let us in and left the cafeteria, so it was just my friend and I in there. We were tryin to find a way to get free snacks, so we stuck our hands up the “drop thingy”, but it didn’t work. We soon realized that it was broken. So we pushed it back, and then reached inside to get free snacks. No one else knew about this except a few of our friends. We only did this one time, and we got about 20+ snacks. It was so funny and crazy. When we were done, we pushed the “drop thingy” back in place to make it seem like it was never broken. I don’t know if they ever checked it to see if it was broken, but we never got caught or in trouble 😂.

Clever, but not 100% effective. In Australia, you will regularly get NZ or Fiji coins from self service checkouts by mistake.

Australia allowed those countries to use the same size shape and composition for their coins, as all were pegged to the GBP. Slowly we all became seperate, and now AUD is worth more than NZD.

When I get a NZ or Fiji coin by accident, I use it in the self service checkout and the cycle continues.

My guard unit deployed down to Panama once about 30 years ago so any statute of limitations has most likely expired, so...

The money in Panama is Balboas and Sentisimos. The value is pegged to the US Dollar and they use US paper currency and don't print any of their own. They do have coins though. They are the same size and value as US coins and are even made in the US mint. Whenever I got change while I was down there, I kept it. I came home with about 50 Balboas (dollars) worth of coins and proceeded to feed the machines in the break room of my civilian job with Panamanian Balboas. Since they were the exact size and material as US coins the machines didn't care. I didn't tell anybody. When the machines started spitting out Panamanian coins in change, much hilarity ensued. The guy that serviced the machines was pretty confused too. I figured I wasn't cheating anyone since the Panamanian currency cost me the same amount of US money as I was supposed to put in the machine.

A while later I told the vending guy where the coins came from. He was cool with it, he said he kept a lot of them as curiosities.

Thx for tip

Vending machines often provide relatively energy-dense snack foods and beverages at a wide variety of points-of-purchase. Vending-machine interventions that stimulate low-calorie choices can therefore play a role in improving the healthfulness of the food environment landscape. The aim of this study is to examine the effects of four vending-machine interventions, varying in level of intrusiveness, on consumers’ choices, consumers’ acceptance of such interventions, and consumers’ evaluations of the choice they made. In a between-subjects design experiment (N = 206), respondents were asked to purchase a snack and a beverage from a vending machine. In addition to a no-intervention condition, four types of incrementally intrusive interventions were implemented: calorie labelling, increasing accessibility of low-calorie choices, increasing prices of high-calorie choices, and restricting availability of high-calorie choices. A post-choice questionnaire included items concerning intervention acceptance, and assortment and choice evaluations. Compared to the no-intervention condition, the most intrusive intervention (i.e. restricting availability of high-calorie choices) led to more low-calorie choices (39% vs. 78%), while less intrusive interventions (i.e. calorie labelling, increasing accessibility of low-calorie choices, and increasing prices of high-calorie choices) did not. Intervention acceptance and choice evaluations were equally high across the four intervention types. Overall, the results suggest that restricting high-calorie options is a promising route to stimulate healthier choices from vending machines. As such, the present study provides intervention opportunities in the combat against obesity for governments and their potential allies, such as food manufacturers and the food service industry.

Back in the days the coin changer had a removable device that the coin first went through called the "slug rejector". There were a series of cradles which the coin would fall through or get caught in and rotated (flipped) on through the process. For coins that had ridges there were wire pickers. They would detect ridges on the coins and accept or reject them.
Nickles would go through the first rocker device (used for quarters) and travel down to the nickle rocker. After it met that test it would roll down a small ramp to the nickle "bouncing block". If it was a good nickle and being heavy enough it would bounce a certain distance and be accepted. If it was not a nickle it would be rejected.
The old coin changers did not have an escrow system. If you put your money in and the product was out that you wanted you had to choose another. You could not get your money back.
The old soft drink machines had 7watt white Christmas tree bulbs for their "sold out" lights. These bulbs would last about 2 weeks and burn out. LED lights came on the scene a couple of decades later.
People would salt the vending machines to get free money or drinks. Putting salt in a milk cartoon and filling it with water and pouring it down the coin slot would drive a vending machine crazy. Most times it will jackpot drinks out as fast as you could pull them out.
I remember one time someone squirted some can insulating foam in the dollar bill accepter. That stuff expanded and hardened. It ruined a $500.00 dollar bill accepter.

The lasers is a very specific vending machine system, its called SureVend, which only select vending machines have. In countries where vending machines may have exchange/refund capability, SureVend usually refunds the customer after 3 retries. In countries where refund/exchange is prohibited (normally this is because they then is legally considered gambling machines and require a gamlings license, since the software COULD be programmed to allow for gambling), the SureVend will attempt vend three times, and then you get the opportunity to select a new product. If all products fail to vend, then the display will usually show a code that you can use later at the same machine when its fixed.

How do toasters cook toast?
When you put in the bread, Lasers detect the size, width and type of bread in the toaster.
Any fake bread falls out the bottom.
Then through an extreme complex series of algorithms and calculations,
the on board CPU sends instructions to the heat regulating transistors which decides how much heat should be dissipated through the grills in comparison to the timer set.
Once completed, micro actuators shift the toast at just the right angle which will ensure the toast will always be stuck in the toaster.
The end result is toast that is uncooked on one side and burnt to a cinder on the other.
